questions.text: Insulin independent absorption occurs in all except:
questions.solution:
GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter that present in skeletal muscle, adipose tissue & heart which is insulin dependent.

Other GLUT receptors which are insulin dependent are GLUT 8, GLUT 12.

Remaining all GLUT receptors are insulin independent.

In brain GLUT 1 is present which is insulin independent.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

  • Choice B: RBC
    • RBCs use GLUT 1, which is insulin-independent and ensures a constant glucose supply.
  • Choice C: Pancreas
    • The pancreas has GLUT 2, which is insulin-independent and allows glucose sensing for insulin secretion in β-cells.
  • Choice D: Brain
    • The brain primarily uses GLUT 1 (blood-brain barrier) and GLUT 3 (neurons), both of which are insulin-independent, ensuring a continuous glucose supply.

Key Takeaway:

Insulin-independent glucose absorption occurs in RBCs, the brain, and the pancreas, but adipose tissue requires insulin via GLUT 4.

choices.text: By decreasing osteoclastioc activity and decreasing renal excretion of calcium

questions.text: The adjoining graph shows the effect of PTH on blood calcium and phosphate in an experimental animal. How does PTH increase plasma calcium?
questions.solution:
Actions of PTH are coordinated to produce an increase in serum [Ca2+ ] and a decrease in serum [phosphate].

The second messenger for PTH actions on its target tissues is cAMP.

  1. PTH increases bone resorption, which brings both Ca 2+ and phosphate from bone mineral into the ECF. Alone, this effect on bone would not increase the serum ionized [Ca2+ ] because phosphate complexes Ca2+ . Resorption of the organic matrix of bone is reflected in increased hydroxyproline excretion.
  2. PTH inhibits renal phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule and, therefore, increases phosphate excretion (phosphaturic effect). As a result, the phosphate resorbed from bone is excreted in the urine, allowing the serum ionized [Ca2+ ] to increase. cAMP generated as a result of the action of PTH on the proximal tubule is excreted in the urine (urinary cAMP).
  3. PTH increases renal Ca 2+ reabsorption in the distal tubule, which also increases the serum [Ca2+ ].
  4. PTH increases intestinal Ca 2+ absorption indirectly by stimulating the production of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol in the kidney

questions.text: The motor supply of the muscle spindle is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Motor Innervation of the Muscle Spindle.

The organization of the muscle spindle:. Each spindle is 3 to 10 millimeters long. It is built around 3 to 12 tiny intrafusal muscle fibers that are pointed at their ends and attached to the glycocalyx of the surrounding large extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers

Each intrafusal muscle fiber is a tiny skeletal muscle fiber. However, the central region of each of these fibersthat is, the area midway between its two ends-has few or no actin and myosin filaments. Therefore, this central portion does not contract when the ends do. Instead, it functions as a sensory receptor, as described later.

The end portions that do contract are excited by small gamma motor nerve fibers that originate from small type A gamma motor neurons in the anterior horns of the spinal cord, as described earlier.

These gamma motor nerve fibers are also called gamma efferent fibers, in contradistinction to the large alpha efferent fibers (type AÎ± nerve fibers) that innervate the extrafusal skeletal muscle.

questions.text: In the adjoining graph of the muscle fibre action potential, the phase marked E is due to which of the following?
questions.solution: Repolarization phase- Sodium channels close and potassium channels open leading to K+ efflux resulting in repolarization .

questions.text: Phase zero is the adjoining image is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Occurs in the SA and AV nodes. Key differences from the ventricular action potential include:

Phase 0 = upstroke-opening of voltage-gated Ca 2+ channels. Fast voltage-gated Na + channels are permanently inactivated because of the less negative resting potential of these cells. Results in a slow conduction velocity that is used by the AV node to prolong transmission from the atria to ventricles. Phases 1 and 2 are absent.

Phase 3 = repolarization-inactivation of the Ca 2+ channels and ↑activation of K + channels -> ↑ K+ efflux.

Phase 4 = slow spontaneous diastolic depolarization due to If ("funny current"). I f channels responsible for a slow, mixed Na + inward/K + outward current; different from I Na in phase 0 of ventricular action potential.

Accounts for automaticity of SA and AV nodes. The slope of phase 4 in the SA node determines HR. ACh/adenosine ↓ the rate of diastolic depolarization and ↓HR, while catecholamines ↑depolarization and ↑ HR. Sympathetic stimulation increases the chance that If channels are open and thus ↑HR.

choices.text: Located in the thick muscle layer
Afferent fibres pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch
Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about baroreceptors?
questions.solution:
In the walls of the bifurcation region of the adventitia (not muscular layer) of carotid arteries in the neck, and also in the arch of the aorta in the thorax, are many nerve receptors called baroreceptors that are stimulated by stretch of the arterial wall.

When arterial pressure rises too high, the baroreceptors send barrages of nerve impulses to the medulla of the brain

Baroreceptors are sensitive to changes in pulse pressure> mean arterial pressure> systolic blood pressure> diastolic blood pressure

Afferents for carotid sinus- glossopharyngeal nerve

Afferents for aortic sinus- vagus nerve

Incorrect Choices Explanation (i.e., Correct Statements):

  • Choice B: Stretch receptors
    • Correct because baroreceptors detect mechanical stretch in response to pressure changes.
  • Choice C: Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch
    • Correct because the carotid sinus baroreceptors send signals through the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla.
    • Aortic arch baroreceptors send signals via the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • Choice D: Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure
    • Correct because baroreceptors sense rapid changes in pulse pressure and regulate mean arterial pressure (MAP).
    • Sensitivity ranking:
      • Pulse pressure > MAP > Systolic BP > Diastolic BP

Key Takeaway:

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitia (not in the thick muscular layer) and function as stretch receptors that detect changes in arterial pressure and relay signals via the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following occur during a cough reflex?
questions.solution: Coughing is protective reflex & example of valsalva maneuver where 1st there will be deep inspiration followed by forceful expiration against closed glottis. Then glottis will open with removal of air or harmful substances

questions.text: The first part of PCT has which of the following transport proteins?
questions.solution:
• PCT reabsorbs 67% of Nacl, water, K+ & filtered urea. 70% of calcium, 100% of glucose & amino acids, 80% of phosphate & bicarbonate.
  • Sodium reabsorption is mainly due to Na+ - H+ antiport
  • Another major transport protein for sodium is SGLT2.
  • Other important sodium transporters in PCT are Na/Pi cotransporter, Na amino acid cotransporter & Na/lactate CT cotransporter.
  • Na+-H+ antiporter is the main determinant of Na & H20 reabsorption in PCT. Na & H+ exchange is linked directly to reabsorption of HCO3- through Na+ Hco3- cotransporter at basal membrane

Key Takeaway:

The first part of the PCT contains Na+/K+ ATPase, Na+-glucose co-transporter (SGLT2), and Na+-H+ antiporter (NHE3), all playing crucial roles in sodium and solute reabsorption.

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following?
questions.solution:
• 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate(2,3-BPG) is found in large amounts in red cells. It is formed from 3-phosphoglyceraldehyde, which is a product of glycolysis via the Embden-Meyerhof pathway.
  • It is a highly charged anion that binds to the β chains of deoxyhemoglobin leading to unloading of oxygen to tissues .
  • One mole of deoxyhemoglobin(Taut form or T form of hemoglobin) binds 1 mol of 2,3-BPG.

Other options:

2,3-BPG does not bind to alpha and gamma chains.

questions.text:
Out of four given statement Which is the appropriate Mechanism of coughing?
1. Forceful expiration against close glottis
2. Expiration against open glottis
3. Deep inspiration against closed glottis
4. Remove harmful substances
Select the answers from the given code:
questions.solution: Coughing is protective reflex & example of valsalva maneuver where 1st there will be deep inspiration followed by forceful expiration against closed glottis. Then glottis will open with removal of air or harmful substances

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the given image. Identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Acromegaly

Excess GH in adults. Typically caused by pituitary adenoma.

Findings

  • Large tongue with deep furrows, frontalbossing, coarsening of facial features with aging A, deep voice, diaphoresis (excessive sweating), hypertrophic arthropathy, impaired glucose tolerance (insulin resistance), HTN, LVH, HFpEF (most common cause of death).

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• First degree heart block:
    • Prolonged PR interval more than 0.20 sec (1:1)
  • Second degree heart block:
    • Mobitz type 1: gradual lengthening of PR interval till P wave isn't followed by a QRS complex. It's also known as Wenckebach's phenomenon.
    • Mobitz type 2: ventricular beat may follow every second (2:1 block) or every third atrial beat (3:1 block)
  • Complete heat block:
    • Third degree heart block, where conduction from atrium to ventricle is totally blocked create idioventricular rhythm.

questions.text: Labelling on zona glomerulosa and function asked
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is of zona glomerulosa which secretes aldosterone

The mechanism involves increased Na + entry into the cells across the luminal membrane and increased pumping of Na + out of the cells by the Na+ -K + pump. Stimulation of the Na+ -K + pump simultaneously increases K + uptake into the principal cells, increasing the intracellular K + concentration and the driving force for K + secretion. Aldosterone also increases the number of luminal membrane K + channels.

So, aldosterone is involved in electrolyte balance

questions.text: Which of the following diagnosis can be inferred from the graph given below?
questions.solution:
FEV 1 is the volume of air that can be expired in the first second of a forced maximal expiration.

FEV 1 is normally 80% of the forced vital capacity, which is expressed as FEV1 / FVC = 0.8

In the above graph FEV1/FVC is 60% which is indicative of obstructive lung pattern

In obstructive lung disease, such as asthma, bronchiectasis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), both FEV 1 and FVC are reduced, but FEV 1 is reduced more than FVC is; thus, FEV1 /FVC is decreased.

In restrictive lung disease, such as fibrosis, both FEV 1 and FVC are reduced, but FEV 1 is reduced less than FVC is; thus, FEV1 /FVC is increased.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

  • Choice A: Chest wall neuromuscular disease
    • Restrictive pattern (FEV1/FVC would be normal or increased).
    • Due to weak inspiratory muscles, lung expansion is restricted, but there is no airway obstruction.
  • Choice B: Sarcoidosis
    • Restrictive pattern (FEV1/FVC would be normal or increased).
    • Granulomatous inflammation in the lungs leads to fibrosis, decreasing lung compliance.
  • Choice C: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis
    • Restrictive disease (FEV1/FVC > 80%).
    • Reduced lung compliance results in proportionally reduced FEV1 and FVC, maintaining or increasing the ratio.

Key Takeaway:

An FEV1/FVC ratio of 60% indicates an obstructive lung disease, and bronchiectasis is the correct diagnosis.

questions.text: patient underwent adrenalectomy and developed pigmentation and fatigue diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Removal of adrenal gland leads to Addison's disease.

Deficiency of mainly 3 hormones

  • Due to mineralocorticoid deficiency:
    • Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, small heart, nausea, vomiting
  • Due to glucocorticoids deficiency:
    • Hypoglycemia, fatigue, anorexia, skin pigmentation, weight loss, myalgia
  • Due to adrenal androgen deficiency:
    • Lack of energy, dry & itchy skin, loss of libido in women & loss of axillary & pubic hairs in women.

questions.text: In the below diagram shows nerve cell physiology, from the given below, the D-E action is caused by?
questions.solution:
The Region marked as D-E refers to the repolarization phase which occurs due to efflux of potassium ions (K+).

Different phases of action potential are:

Resting state- Both sodium and potassium voltage-gated channels are closed. The membrane is said to be "polarized" during this stage because of the −70 millivolts negative membrane potential that is present.

Depolarization phase- Sodium channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus resulting in influx of sodium ions. The membrane reaches threshold potential. Sodium influx leads to opening of more sodium channels due to positive feedback leading to rapid depolarization.

Repolarization phase- Sodium channels close and potassium channels open leading to K+ efflux resulting in repolarization .

After Hyperpolarization phase- Slow efflux of K+ continues even after the resting membrane potential is reached resulting in a prolonged phase of hyperpolarization.

At last both channels are closed and the membrane returns to Resting Membrane Potential (RMP).

questions.text: Entry of glucose which is insulin dependent except:
questions.solution:
GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter that present in skeletal muscle, adipose tissue & heart which is insulin dependent.

Other GLUT receptors which are insulin dependent are GLUT 8, GLUT 12.

Remaining all GLUT receptors are insulin independent.

In brain GLUT 1 is present which is insulin independent.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism through which parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases blood calcium levels?
questions.solution:
Actions of PTH are coordinated to produce an increase in serum [Ca2+ ] and a decrease in serum [phosphate].

  1. PTH increases bone resorption, which brings both Ca 2+ and phosphate from bone mineral into the ECF. Alone, this effect on bone would not increase the serum ionized [Ca2+ ] because phosphate complexes Ca2+ . Resorption of the organic matrix of bone is reflected in increased hydroxyproline excretion.
  2. PTH inhibits renal phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule and, therefore, increases phosphate excretion (phosphaturic effect). As a result, the phosphate resorbed from bone is excreted in the urine, allowing the serum ionized [Ca2+ ] to increase. cAMP generated as a result of the action of PTH on the proximal tubule is excreted in the urine (urinary cAMP).
  3. PTH increases renal Ca 2+ reabsorption in the distal tubule, which also increases the serum [Ca2+ ].
  4. PTH increases intestinal Ca 2+ absorption indirectly by stimulating the production of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol in the kidney

choices.text: One-layer cells in inner hair cells, 3-layer cells in outer hair cells
Maximum nerve fibres supply inner cells

questions.text: All of the following statements are true?
questions.solution:
Hair cells:

  • They are important receptor cells of hearing and transduce sound energy into electrical energy.
  • Inner hair cells form a single row while outer hair cells are arranged in three or four rows. Inner hair cells are richly supplied by afferent cochlear fibres and are probably more important in the transmission of auditory impulses.
  • Outer hair cells mainly receive efferent innervation from the olivary complex and are concerned with modulating the function of inner hair cells
